I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  to  the  Democratic  Socialist  Republic  of  Sri  Lanka  for  the 
Greater Colombo Water and Wastewater Management Improvement Investment Program.1 The 
investment  program  will  finance  a  portion  of  government  initiatives  to  improve  water  and 
wastewater  management  services  in  Greater  Colombo. 2 It  will  rehabilitate  and  expand  water 
supply and wastewater management infrastructure. For investments in physical infrastructure to 
be  effective  and  sustainable, the  investment  program  will  assist the government  in  introducing 
institutional reforms in the water and wastewater subsectors, particularly in Greater Colombo.3
 

  

II. 

THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
Water. About 95% of Colombo,4 the capital city and economic and administrative hub of 
2. 
the  country,  is  covered  by  a  piped  water  supply  system.  Because  the  system  has  low  and 
fluctuating system pressure and intermittent supply, some areas of the city receive water only in 
off-peak hours and others receive water for an average of only 6–10 hours a day. Many parts of 
the distribution network were built more than 100 years ago.5 Though there have been various 
projects to address the increasing water demand, significant network rehabilitation has not been 
carried  out;  nonrevenue  water  (NRW)  remains  around  49%.6
 The  National  Water  Supply  and 
Drainage Board (NWSDB), under the Ministry of Water Supply and Drainage (MWSD), supplies 
piped  water  to  127,000  metered  service  connections  in  Colombo;  in  the  underserved 
settlements,  about  3,200  standposts  are  not  metered.  The  water  tariff  is  below  full  cost 
recovery.  To  enhance  water  conservation  through  the  standposts  in  underserved  settlements, 
NWSDB  has  launched  various  pilot  programs  across  the  country  and  specifically  in  Colombo. 
These programs need to be implemented on a larger scale. 
 
3. 
Wastewater.  According to  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme,  in  2008,  66% 
of the Greater Colombo population had on-site sanitation facilities; 25% had sewerage systems; 
and  9%  had  no  facilities  and  disposed  of  waste  on  the  seashore,  into  canals  and  waterways, 
and on available open ground. The various sewerage systems operating within Greater Colombo 
are  currently  estimated  to  serve  140,000  households.  The  sewer  network,  built  from  1906  to 
2007, comprises about 320 kilometers (km) of sewers, 18 pumping stations in two catchments 
(north and south), and two sea outfalls. The sewer lines have frequent collapses and blockages, 
and  one-third  of  the  pumping  facilities  are  not  working,  causing  frequent  overflow  into 
watercourses.  The  Colombo  Municipal  Council  (CMC)  owns  and  operates  the  wastewater 
infrastructure services in Colombo, and is the only municipal body handling such service in the 
country. NWSDB manages wastewater facilities outside the CMC area. NWSDB has introduced 
a  sewerage  tariff  within  its  operating  jurisdiction  and  has  a  dedicated  account  for  sewerage

NRW reduction. NWSDB’s limited network rehabilitation and leak repairs under routine 
4. 
operation and maintenance (O&M) have had little impact on NRW reduction. A focused program 
of pipe replacement and metering, implemented in a small part of the critical area8 in Colombo 
with  funding  from  the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  (JICA), 9
brought  about  local 
improvements. According to the water balance for Colombo dated January 2012, the estimated 
annual  revenue  losses  associated  with  NRW  are  more  than  SLRs1.7  billion  ($13 million). The 
government recognizes that focused efforts, including citywide NRW reduction and institutional 
reforms, are needed to improve service and increase water availability in Colombo, and manage 
the increasing demand. However, these plans are hampered by lack of budget and institutional 
reforms.  The  high  rate  of  NRW  remains  the  greatest  obstacle  to  improving  NWSDB’s 
performance and financial viability. 
 
include 
5. 
(i) inefficient and unreliable infrastructure performance, as a result of inadequate asset planning 
and  management  and  associated  investments,  (ii)  inadequate  and  fragmented  organizational 
structures  that  do  not  promote  accountability  and  performance,  (iii)  low  cost  recovery  (for 
sewerage), and (iv) inadequate operating and monitoring capacity of service providers. 
 
6. 
Road  map.  The  MFF  is  to  support  the  government  in  achieving  its  water  supply  and 
wastewater sector targets under its development policy framework (DPF), which has objectives 
to  (i)  reduce  and  manage  NRW  holistically  and  sustainably;  (ii)  improve  governance, 
management capacity, and accountability within NWSDB and CMC; and (iii) improve water and 
wastewater  service  delivery  and  amounts  in  Greater  Colombo.  10
 It  includes  plans  to  increase 
the national coverage of piped water supply from 37% to 60%, and piped sewerage from 2.5% 
to  7%  during  2010–2020.  Improving  municipal  services,  specifically  in  water  supply  and 
wastewater,  is  a  key  government  priority.  The  government  recognizes  that  focused  efforts, 
including Colombo citywide NRW reduction and institutional reforms, are necessary to improve 
service and increase water availability in Colombo to manage increasing demand. 
 
7. 
Policy and regulatory framework. Under the DPF, in 2010 MWSD adopted the National 
Drinking  Water  Policy  and  the  National  Policy  on  Sanitation  to  provide  guidance  to  NWSDB, 
provincial  councils,  local  authorities,  lending  institutions,  and  organizations  involved  in 
delivering water supply and sanitation services. In 2003, Parliament authorized the formation of 
the  Public  Utilities  Commission  to  regulate  electricity,  petroleum,  and  water  tariffs.  Despite 
several  drafts  of  the  NWSDB  Water  Bill  and  amendments  to  the  NWSDB  Act,  water  tariff 
regulation  is  still  not  in  place  under  the  commission.  But  even  without  an  independent  water 
regulatory framework, NWSDB still managed to increase tariffs to meet operating requirements, 
most recently in 2009. Further tariff increases are necessary for full cost recovery. 

                                                
7  The cabinet approved the introduction of a sewerage charge in September 2002. Subsequently, NWSDB approved 
a sewerage tariff policy and a specific tariff structure, which MWSD approved. A new sewerage tariff was gazetted 
in October 2007 and implemented in March 2008. As part of system computerization at NWSDB, the water bill form 
was modified and the sewerage charge was incorporated into the water bill. 

8  North  of  Colombo  and  covering  12  square  km,  the  area  comprises  Kotahena,  Modera,  Grandpass,  and 

Mattakkuliya.

3 

 
8. 
Government  strategy  and  investment  plan.  To  achieve  the  DPF  targets  for  water 
supply  and  sanitation for  Greater  Colombo,  NWSDB  and  CMC  need to  provide  the  population 
with  (i) full  coverage  and  24-hour  water  supply  in  Colombo  and  universal  safe  water  supply  in 
Greater  Colombo;  and  (ii)  universal  sanitation  coverage  in  Greater  Colombo,  with  100% 
connection to public sewers in Colombo. NWSDB and CMC have adopted an investment plan 
comprising intervention and project requirements to achieve these targets.11
 The plan envisions 
investments  of  $1,500  million  in  2010–2020.  NWSDB’s  corporate  plan  (2012–2016)  includes 
goals of increasing water supply and sanitation coverage and improving business efficiency and 
services  to  customers.  The  business  efficiency  objectives  specifically  target  NRW  reduction  in 
Colombo and nationally. 
 
Investment program. The investment program will support the government in achieving 
9. 
its  water  supply  and  wastewater  targets  under  the  DPF  for  Greater  Colombo.  Supplementing 
ongoing  projects  and  expected  funds  from  other  development  partners,  such  as  JICA  and 
NWSDB, Asian Development Bank (ADB) financing of $300 million under the MFF will provide 
100% of the investment needed to achieve the water supply targets ($164 million) and 85% of 
the investment needed to achieve the wastewater targets ($136 million) for Colombo. The MFF, 
therefore, will fund about 20% of the $1,500 million financing needed by the government under 
its  investment  plan  for  water  and  sanitation  in  Greater  Colombo.  Global  best  practice  and 
proven  approaches  to  NRW  reduction  will  be  used  to  reduce  NRW,  from  the  current  49%  to 
20%  in  Colombo,  and  from  about  60%  to  18%  in  critical  areas,  by  the  end  of  the  investment 
program  in  2020.  Wastewater  will  meet  the  discharge  target  set  by  the  Central  Environment 
Authority.  
 
10.  MFF  and  tranches.  The  MFF  modality  was  selected  to  allow  phased  implementation 
and  funding  of  individual  projects  when  they  are  ready,  subject  to  eligibility  and  readiness  of 
subprojects included in the investment program. The requirements for an MFF are in place. The 
government  has  prepared  a  sector  strategy  supported  by  an  investment  plan  for  the  next  
8 years.12
 The MFF will be sequenced: (i) tranche 1: $84 million for project 1 in 2012; (ii) tranche 
2:  $80  million  for  project  2  in  2013;  (iii)  tranche  3:  $100  million  for  project  3  in  2015;  and  (iv) 
tranche  4:  $36  million for  project  4  in  2016.  Projects  1  and  2  will focus on  reducing  NRW and 
improving water service efficiency in Colombo. Project 1 will be implemented from 2012 to 2016. 
Projects 3 and 4 will support improved wastewater services, including treatment, and expansion 
of  service  coverage  in  Greater  Colombo.  The  government  has  asked  ADB  for  assistance  in 
exploring possibilities for cofinancing under the investment plan.  
 
ADB strategy. ADB is one of the major development partners13 involved in water supply 
11. 
and sanitation in Sri Lanka, providing eight loan projects for a total of about $521 million since 
1986.  Lessons 14
 from  the  involvement  of  ADB  and  other  development  partners  were 
incorporated into the investment program design. The investment program is consistent with the 
priority  assigned  by  ADB  and  the  government  to  the  water  supply  and  other  municipal

B. 
 
12. 
The impact will be an improved urban environment and quality of life for the residents of 
Greater  Colombo.  The  outcome  will  be  improved  water  supply  and  wastewater  service  and 
management in Greater Colombo.  
 
C. 
 
13. 
Output  1:  Rehabilitated  and  expanded water  supply  system  and  reduced  NRW  in 
Colombo.  The  investment  program  supports  (i)  rehabilitating  and  replacing  the  water  supply 
distribution  network,  pumps,  and  transmission  pipes  for  Colombo;  (ii)  enhancing  domestic 
service  connections,  including  installing  higher-quality  customer  meters;  (iii) validating  the 
geographic  information  system  (GIS)  network  maps;  (iv) implementing  citywide  active  leakage 
control  using  fully  equipped  NRW  teams;  (v)   reinforcing  the  O&M  unit  to  undertake  major 
repairs;  (vi) establishing  an  NRW  monitoring  and  control  system  based  on  a  zone  distribution 
system  (i.e.,  district  metered  areas);  and  (vii)  providing  materials,  equipment,  vehicles,  and 
NRW buildings. Project 1 will focus on rehabilitation of pipe distribution in north Colombo. 
 
14. 
Output  2:  Improved  wastewater  services  in  Greater  Colombo.  The  investment 
program  supports  (i)  rehabilitating  and  expanding  existing  sewers;  (ii)  providing  sewer 
connections;  and  (iii) constructing  two  wastewater  treatment  plants  (total  capacity  of  175,000 
cubic meters/day).  

 
15. 
Output  3:  Strengthened  institutional  structure  and  capacity  of  service  providers. 
The  investment  program  will  support  (i)  establishing  an  operations  performance  audit  cell  in 
NWSDB;  (ii)  decentralizing  all  Colombo  water  supply  operations  to  the  Western  Central 
Regional Support Center (RSC-WC), to be an autonomous business center under NWSDB; (iii) 
delegating  asset,  management,  and  investment  planning  to  RSC-WC;  (iv)  establishing  a  GIS-
based  asset  management  system  for  water  and  wastewater  in  Colombo;  (v)  separating 
sewerage and drainage into two functional departments and establishing a separate accounting 
system  for  wastewater  services;  (vi)  preparing  bid  documents  for  build–operate–transfer 
contracts for the wastewater treatment plants; (vii) introducing a wastewater volumetric tariff in 
CMC to recover O&M costs, and methodology, and guiding studies supporting the cost-recovery 
tariff; (viii) providing management advisory and supervision consultants to support investments 
in the water subsector and managing NRW reduction and design, supervision, and institutional 
consultants  to  support  implementation  of  wastewater  investments;  (ix)  providing  a  public 
awareness  campaign  including  nongovernment  organizations  in  the  investment  program 
activities; and (x) providing training and capacity building to improve the operating performance 
of  staff.  Project  1  will  focus  on  strengthened  institutional  structure  and  capacity  in  relation  to 
NRW reduction. 
 
16. 
Output  4:  Investment  program  implemented.  The  investment  program  will  provide 
implementation support for the executing and implementing agencies to manage the investment 
program  successfully,  and  to  prepare  the  remaining  tranches  by  enhancing  the  facilities  and 
providing on-the-job training with consultants’ day-to-day collaboration.

The government has requested an MFF in an amount up to $300 million equivalent, or 
75%  of  the  total  investment  program  cost,  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources  and  ordinary 
capital  resources (OCR)  to  help finance  a  part  of the  investment  program  (Table  2). The  MFF

fulfillment  of  terms  and  conditions  and  undertakings  set  forth  in  the  framework  financing

19. 
The government will contribute $100 million, or 25% of the total investment program cost 
to finance taxes and duties, resettlement costs, and part of the civil works and recurrent costs. It 
will  relend  relevant  portions  of  the  loan  proceeds  to  NWSDB  on  a  50%  grant  and  50%  loan 
basis  for  financing  capital  investment  costs  in  the  water  subsector,  and  to  CMC  on  a  82.5% 
grant  and  17.5%  loan  basis  in  the  wastewater  subsector,  in  accordance  with  established 
procedures.  These  arrangements  will  be  described  in  subsidiary  financing  agreements, 
satisfactory to ADB, to be signed and effective before NWSDB and CMC can receive the loan 
proceeds and the counterpart funds. The government will assume the foreign exchange risk.

25. 
The estimated financial internal rate of return (FIRR) for the water supply improvement 
project, including projects 1 and 2, is 6.25%; the net present value is $75 million at the weighted 
average  cost  of  capital  (WACC)  of  2.95%.  The  FIRR  is  higher  than  the  WACC,  indicating  a 
reasonable  financial  return.  The  result  is  robust  against  downside  risks,  as  assessed  in  the 
sensitivity  analysis,  with  (i)  capital  costs  increased  by  20%,  (ii)  O&M  costs  increased  by  20%, 
(iii)  revenues  reduced  by  20%,  and  (iv)  project  implementation  delayed  by  1 year.  The  FIRR 
varies from 4.32% to 5.54%; it is 2.12% when all risks are assumed to occur at the same time. 
The  most  sensitive  risk  factor  is  a  decrease  in  revenues,  followed  by  capital  cost  overrun.

26. 
An  economic  analysis  was  conducted  for  projects  1  and  2  of  the  investment  program. 
The estimated economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the combined projects is 16.9%; the 
net present value is $44 million at the economic opportunity cost of capital of 12%. The EIRR is 
higher than the economic opportunity cost of capital, indicating a sufficient economic return. The 
result  is  robust  against downside  risks,  including  (i) capital cost  overrun  of  20%, (ii) O&M  cost 
overrun  of  20%,  (iii)  benefits  reduced  by  20%,  and  (iv)  project  implementation  delayed  by  1 
year. The EIRRs range from 13.4% to 16.6% in the sensitivity analysis; the EIRR is 10% when 
all  risks  are  assumed  to  occur  at  the  same  time.  Sensitivity  analysis  shows  that  EIRRs  are 
generally  robust  to  the  downside  risks  and  are  most  sensitive  to  a  reduction  in  benefits. 
Satisfactory  project  benefits  are considered  attainable,  as  the  large  and  growing  population  of 
Greater Colombo, including the floating population of 500,000, will benefit from expanded water 
supply service coverage as a result of the water improvement project, which will provide about 
30 million cubic meters of water per year to enhance the water supply system.

Safeguards 

E. 

29. 
Social safeguards. Project 1 is classified under category B for involuntary resettlement 
and  category  C for  indigenous  peoples  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
(2009). A draft resettlement plan endorsed by the government was prepared and disclosed for 
project 1 in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement to address potential temporary 
income losses within the project area during linear pipe rehabilitation works, including temporary 
disruption  of  approximately  7,600  mobile  vendors  and  hawkers for  less than  7  days.  Full  road 
closure is not anticipated and work in busy commercial areas will be done during nonbusiness 
hours (i.e., nighttime) to the extent possible. Counterpart funds are budgeted to compensate for 
potential income losses before displacement. NWSDB has implemented previous ADB projects 
and  is  familiar  with  ADB’s  safeguard  policies;  however,  the  management  advisory  and 
supervision consultants will provide additional capacity support to counterpart staff new to ADB 
projects  and  to  help  manage  and  monitor  resettlement  impacts  and  social  risks  during  the 
investment program. The project management unit (PMU) will provide social safeguard reports 
to ADB every 6 months. A resettlement framework was prepared to guide resettlement planning 
in  future  tranches.  Considering  the  urban  setting  of  the  project  and  socioeconomic  survey 
results  within  the  investment  program  area,  no  impacts  on  indigenous  peoples  are  expected, 
and an indigenous peoples planning framework is not required. 29
 
Environmental  safeguards.  Project  1  is  classified  under  category  B  for  environment. 
30. 
An environmental assessment and review framework was prepared to guide the preparation of 
future tranches, and an initial environmental examination30
 with an environmental management 
plan  was  prepared  for  project  1  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  and 
government  laws.  The  draft  initial  environmental  examination  concludes  that  no  significant 
adverse  impact  is  anticipated  as  a  result  of  the  water  distribution  network  improvements,  and 
that net environmental benefits to Colombo’s population will be positive and large as a result of 
the  increased  reliability  of  water  supply.  It  outlines  a  grievance  redress  mechanism  to  ensure 
easy  and  quick  redress  of  any  complaints  or  concerns  during  project  implementation.  The 
environmental  management  plan  provides  adequate  mitigation  measures  for  any  foreseen 
construction impact, including traffic management to ensure limited disruption to traffic flow and 
access. Support from the management advisory and supervision consultants will ensure that the 
PMU  has  adequate  capacity  to  manage  any  environmental  impact  during  detailed  design  and 
construction. The PMU will provide ADB with a report on environmental issues every 6 months.
